<ralexstokes> this may be getting too deep into the weeds but why do you use multiple powers of `r`, rather than just use a single `r`?

i'm guessing if don't use powers of `r` then the result is not an actual polynomial?

author: bridge-bot
content: <asn_d6> hmm. that's how the random linear combination things usually works. you basically want all the random factors of the linear combination (the powers of r in our case) to be unpredictable so that an adversary cannot do evil things. evil things could include stuff like "make commitment C_2 be the inverse of C_1" such that it cancels out in the lincomb (this is an outrageous implausible example). that attack couldbe possible if all the random factors are the same (a single `r`).

author: bridge-bot
content: <adietrichs> Basically the intuition is that checking the one combined proof is supposed to be equivalent to checking each individual one separately. If the relative weights of the commitments to each other would be predictable, you could construct fake data where the deviation of the individual blobs from the correct ones is constructed so that in the aggregate it cancels out and the check passes

<gakonst> Forwarded from pratyush795: The reason why is because a univariate polynomial of degree d has at most d+1 roots. Assume the linear combination sums to zero, and let the elements being combined be a_i. Then the polynomial a_0 + a_1‚Ä¢x + ‚Ä¶ + a_d x^d is zero at the random challenge r with probability at most d/|F|, where F is the field.

Since r is chosen randomly after the a_i‚Äôs have been committed, it‚Äôs independent of them
